content: Whites Told to "Go Home" at Detroit City Council Meeting Monica Conyers, wife of Rep. John Conyers, with Reverend Al Sharpton and indicted former Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick of Detroit. Here's the latest from the cesspool once known as Detroit. Keep it classy, racist Democrats. Detroit News reported: Nowhere is Michigan's brain drain on greater display than in the Detroit City Council chambers. My hopes for Detroit's future faded as I watched the tape of last Tuesday's council meeting, the one that considered the Cobo Center expansion deal. It was a tragic circus, a festival of ignorance that confirmed the No. 1 obstacle to Detroit's progress is the bargain basement leaders that city voters elect. The black nationalism that is now the dominant ideology of the council was on proud display, both at the table and in the audience. Speakers advocating for the deal were taunted by the crowd and cut short by Council President Monica Conyers, who presided over the hearing like an angry bulldog; whites were advised by the citizens to, "Go home." Opponents were allowed to rant and ramble on uninterrupted about "those people" who want to steal Detroit's assets and profit from the city's labors. A pitiful Teamster official who practically crawled to the table on his knees expressing profuse respect for this disrespectful body was battered by both the crowd and the council. When he dared suggest that an improved Cobo Center would create more good-paying jobs for union workers, Conyers reminded him, "Those workers look like you; they don't look like me." Desperate, he invoked President Barack Obama's message of unity and was angrily warned, "Don't yousay his name here." Juxtapose the place and the faces and imagine a white Livonia City Council treating a black union representative with such overt racial hostility. The Justice Department would swoop down like a hawk, and the Rev. Al Sharpton would clog Five Mile Road with protesters.

content: quote: Remember what happened in Detroit in the 60s? Looks like they're asking for it again!!! Only a lot worse!!! Those riots were pretty wide spread. I was still in school but worked at a store in Hackensack, NJ. that sold, among other things, guns. We were told to remove all guns and ammo and be prepared to close. Yeah right, we laid in a big supply of food and whatever else we needed. Than we loaded up all of the biggest nastiest weapons we had and made them easily reachable. Fortunately the riots didn't come to Hackensack. There was a nearby city by the name of Patterson, NJ. Patterson was very much like Detroit. When the rioters started massing, the mayor was ready. He had the entire police department heavy armed as was he. He stood in the middle of the street and said that they would make no effort at any riot control. His people would simply shoot and shoot to kill. The last thing he said was that he would be the one to fire the first shot. Guess what? The rioters all seemed to remember something else they had to do. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

content: quote: Remember what happened in Detroit in the 60s? Looks like they're asking for it again!!! Only a lot worse!!! Those riots were pretty wide spread. I was still in school but worked at a store in Hackensack, NJ. that sold, among other things, guns. We were told to remove all guns and ammo and be prepared to close. Yeah right, we laid in a big supply of food and whatever else we needed. Than we loaded up all of the biggest nastiest weapons we had and made them easily reachable. Fortunately the riots didn't come to Hackensack. There was a nearby city by the name of Patterson, NJ. Patterson was very much like Detroit. When the rioters started massing, the mayor was ready. He had the entire police department heavy armed as was he. He stood in the middle of the street and said that they would make no effort at any riot control. His people would simply shoot and shoot to kill. The last thing he said was that he would be the one to fire the first shot. Guess what? The rioters all seemed to remember something else they had to do. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
